On the Secrecy Capacity of Fading Channels

Praveen Kumar Gopala, Lifeng Lai and Hesham El Gamal
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
The Ohio State University
Columbus, OH 43210
Email: {gopalap,lail,helgamal}@ece.osu.edu
Abstract

We consider the secure transmission of information over an ergodic fading channel in the presence of an eavesdropper. Our eavesdropper can be viewed as the wireless counterpart of Wyner‚Äôs wiretapper. The secrecy capacity of such a system is characterized under the assumption of asymptotically long coherence intervals. We first consider the full Channel State Information (CSI) case, where the transmitter has access to the channel gains of the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper. The secrecy capacity under this full CSI assumption serves as an upper bound for the secrecy capacity when only the CSI of the legitimate receiver is known at the transmitter, which is characterized next. In each scenario, the perfect secrecy capacity is obtained along with the optimal power and rate allocation strategies. We then propose a low-complexity on/off power allocation strategy that achieves near-optimal performance with only the main channel CSI. More specifically, this scheme is shown to be asymptotically optimal as the average SNR goes to infinity, and interestingly, is shown to attain the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption. Remarkably, our results reveal the positive impact of fading on the secrecy capacity and establish the critical role of rate adaptation, based on the main channel CSI, in facilitating secure communications over slow fading channels.

1 Introduction

The notion of information-theoretic secrecy was first introduced by Shannon [1]. This strong notion of secrecy does not rely on any assumptions on the computational resources of the eavesdropper. More specifically, perfect information-theoretic secrecy requires that I‚Å¢(W;Z)=0ùêºùëäùëç0I(W;Z)=0italic_I ( italic_W ; italic_Z ) = 0, i.e., the signal ZùëçZitalic_Z received by the eavesdropper does not provide any additional information about the transmitted message WùëäWitalic_W. Shannon considered a scenario where both the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper have direct access to the transmitted signal. Under this model, he proved a negative result implying that the achievability of perfect secrecy requires the entropy of the private key KùêæKitalic_K, used to encrypt the message WùëäWitalic_W, to be larger than or equal to the entropy of the message itself (i.e., H‚Å¢(K)‚â•H‚Å¢(W)ùêªùêæùêªùëäH(K)\geq H(W)italic_H ( italic_K ) ‚â• italic_H ( italic_W ) for perfect secrecy). However, it was later shown by Wyner in [2] that this negative result was a consequence of the over-restrictive model used in¬†[1]. Wyner introduced the wiretap channel which accounts for the difference in the two noise processes, as observed by the destination and wiretapper. In this model, the wiretapper has no computational limitations and is assumed to know the codebook used by the transmitter. Under the assumption that the wiretapper‚Äôs signal is a degraded version of the destination‚Äôs signal, Wyner characterized the tradeoff between the information rate to the destination and the level of ignorance at the wiretapper (measured by its equivocation), and showed that it is possible to achieve a non-zero secrecy capacity. This work was later extended to non-degraded channels by Csisza¬¥¬¥ùëé\acute{a}over¬¥ start_ARG italic_a end_ARGr and K√∂rner [3], where it was shown that if the main channel is less noisy or more capable than the wiretapper channel, then it is possible to achieve a non-zero secrecy capacity.

More recently, the effect of slow fading on the secrecy capacity was studied in [8, 9]. In these works, it is assumed that the fading is quasi-static which leads to an alternative definition of outage probability, wherein secure communications can be guaranteed only for the fraction of time when the main channel is stronger than the channel seen by the eavesdropper. This performance metric appears to have an operational significance only in delay sensitive applications with full Channel State Information (CSI). The absence of CSI sheds doubt on the operational significance of outage-based secrecy since it limits the ability of the source to know which parts of the message are decoded by the eavesdropper. In this paper, we focus on delay-tolerant applications which allow for the adoption of an ergodic version of the slow fading channel, instead of the outage-based formulation. Quite interestingly, we show in the sequel that, under this model, one can achieve a perfectly secure non-zero rate even when the eavesdropper channel is more capable then the legitimate channel on the average. In particular, our work here characterizes the secrecy capacity of the slow fading channel in the presence of an eavesdropper [10]. Our eavesdropper is the wireless counterpart of Wyner‚Äôs wiretapper. We first assume that the transmitter knows the CSI of both the legitimate and eavesdropper channels, and derive the optimal power allocation strategy that achieves the secrecy capacity. Next we consider the case where the transmitter only knows the legitimate channel CSI and, again, derive the optimal power allocation strategy. We then propose an on/off power transmission scheme, with variable rate allocation, which approaches the optimal performance for asymptotically large average SNR. Interestingly, this scheme is also shown to attain the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption which implies that, at high SNR values, the additional knowledge of the eavesdropper CSI does not yield any gains in terms of the secrecy capacity for slow fading channels. Finally, our theoretical and numerical results are used to argue that rate adaptation plays a more critical role than power control in achieving the secrecy capacity of slow fading channels. This observation contrasts the scenario without secrecy constraints, where transmission strategies with constant rate are able to achieve capacity¬†[4].

2 System Model

The system model is illustrated in Fig.¬†1. The source SùëÜSitalic_S communicates with a destination Dùê∑Ditalic_D in the presence of an eavesdropper Eùê∏Eitalic_E. During any coherence interval iùëñiitalic_i, the signal received by the destination and the eavesdropper are given by, respectively

where gM‚Å¢(i),gE‚Å¢(i)subscriptùëîùëÄùëñsubscriptùëîùê∏ùëñg_{M}(i),g_{E}(i)italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) are the channel gains from the source to the legitimate receiver (main channel) and the eavesdropper (eavesdropper channel) respectively, and wM‚Å¢(i),wE‚Å¢(i)subscriptùë§ùëÄùëñsubscriptùë§ùê∏ùëñw_{M}(i),w_{E}(i)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) represent the i.i.d additive Gaussian noise with unit variance at the destination and the eavesdropper respectively. We denote the fading power gains of the main and eavesdropper channels by hM‚Å¢(i)=|gM‚Å¢(i)|2subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëÄùëñ2h_{M}(i)=|g_{M}(i)|^{2}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) = | italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and hE‚Å¢(i)=|gE‚Å¢(i)|2subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùê∏ùëñ2h_{E}(i)=|g_{E}(i)|^{2}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) = | italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. We assume that both channels experience block fading, where the channel gains remain constant during each coherence interval and change independently from one coherence interval to the next. The fading process is assumed to be ergodic with a bounded continuous distribution. Moreover, the fading coefficients of the destination and the eavesdropper in any coherence interval are assumed to be independent of each other. We further assume that the number of channel uses n1subscriptùëõ1n_{1}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT within each coherence interval is large enough to allow for invoking random coding arguments. As shown in the sequel, this assumption is instrumental in our achievability proofs.

The source wishes to send a message W‚ààùí≤={1,2,‚ãØ,M}ùëäùí≤12‚ãØùëÄW\in{\mathcal{W}}=\{1,2,\cdots,M\}italic_W ‚àà caligraphic_W = { 1 , 2 , ‚ãØ , italic_M } to the destination. An (M,n)ùëÄùëõ(M,n)( italic_M , italic_n ) code consists of the following elements: 1) a stochastic encoder fn(.)f_{n}(.)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( . ) at the source that maps the message111The realizations of the random variables W,X,Y,ZùëäùëãùëåùëçW,X,Y,Zitalic_W , italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z are represented by w,x,y,zùë§ùë•ùë¶ùëßw,x,y,zitalic_w , italic_x , italic_y , italic_z respectively in the sequel. wùë§witalic_w to a codeword xn‚ààùí≥nsuperscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùí≥ùëõx^{n}\in{\mathcal{X}}^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and 2) a decoding function œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï: ùí¥n‚Üíùí≤‚Üísuperscriptùí¥ùëõùí≤{\mathcal{Y}}^{n}\rightarrow{\mathcal{W}}caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí caligraphic_W at the legitimate receiver. The average error probability of an (M,n)ùëÄùëõ(M,n)( italic_M , italic_n ) code at the legitimate receiver is defined as

In this paper we consider only perfect secrecy which requires the equivocation rate ResubscriptùëÖùëíR_{e}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be equal to the message rate. (3)

Throughout the sequel, we assume that the CSI is known at the destination perfectly. Based on the available CSI, the transmitter adapts its transmission power and rate to maximize the perfect secrecy rate subject to a long-term average power constraint P¬Ø¬ØùëÉ\bar{P}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG.

3 Full CSI at the Transmitter

Here we assume that at the beginning of each coherence interval, the transmitter knows the channel states of the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper perfectly. When hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hEsubscript‚Ñéùê∏h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are both known at the transmitter, one would expect the optimal scheme to allow for transmission only when hM>hEsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏h_{M}>h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and to adapt the transmitted power according to the instantaneous values of hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hEsubscript‚Ñéùê∏h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The following result formalizes this intuitive argument.

Theorem 1

When the channel gains of both the legitimate receiver and the eavesdropper are known at the transmitter, the secrecy capacity is given by

Cs(F)=maxP‚Å¢(hM,hE)‚Å¢‚à´0‚àû‚à´hE‚àû[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))]‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE,superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë†ùêπsubscriptùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏superscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscriptsubscript‚Ñéùê∏delimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏C_{s}^{(F)}~{}=~{}\max\limits_{P(h_{M},h_{E})}\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{h_{E}}^{\infty}\Big{[}\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)\Big{]}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E},italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (4)
such that¬†ùîº‚Å¢{P‚Å¢(hM,hE)}‚â§P¬Ø.such that¬†ùîºùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏¬ØùëÉ\mbox{such that }\qquad\qquad{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M},h_{E})\}~{}\leq~{}\bar{P}.such that blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } ‚â§ over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG . (5)

Proof:¬†¬† A detailed proof of achievability and the converse part is provided in the Appendix. Here, we outline the scheme used in the achievability part. In this scheme, transmission occurs only when hM>hEsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏h_{M}>h_{E}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and uses the power allocation policy P‚Å¢(hM,hE)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) that satisfies the average power constraint (5). Moreover, the codeword rate at each instant is set to be log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), which varies according to the instantaneous channel gains. The achievable perfect secrecy rate at any instant is then given by [log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))]+.superscriptdelimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)]^{+}.[ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Averaging over all fading realizations, we get the average achievable perfect secrecy rate as

Rs(F)superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùêπ\displaystyle R_{s}^{(F)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =\displaystyle== ‚à¨[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))]+‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhEdouble-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\displaystyle\iint\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}‚à¨ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=\displaystyle== ‚à´0‚àû‚à´hE‚àû[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE))]‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE.superscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscriptsubscript‚Ñéùê∏delimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{h_{E}}^{\infty}\Big{[}\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})\right)\Big{]}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{}.‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

One can then optimize over all feasible power control policies P‚Å¢(hM,hE)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to maximize the perfect secrecy rate. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

We now derive the optimal power allocation policy that achieves the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption. It is easy to check that the objective function is concave in P‚Å¢(hM,hE)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and hence, by using the Lagrangian maximization approach for solving (4), we get the following optimality condition

‚àÇRs(F)‚àÇP‚Å¢(hM,hE)=hM1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE)‚àíhE1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,hE)‚àíŒª=0,superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùêπùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùúÜ0\frac{\partial R_{s}^{(F)}}{\partial P(h_{M},h_{E})}~{}=~{}\frac{h_{M}}{1+h_{M}P(h_{M},h_{E})}-\frac{h_{E}}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M},h_{E})}-\lambda~{}=~{}0,divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG - italic_Œª = 0 ,

whose solution is

P‚Å¢(hM,hE)=12‚Å¢[(1hE‚àí1hM)2+4Œª‚Å¢(1hE‚àí1hM)‚àí(1hM+1hE)].ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏12delimited-[]superscript1subscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ24ùúÜ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})~{}=~{}\frac{1}{2}\left[\sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{h_{E}}-\frac{1}{h_{M}}\right)^{2}+\frac{4}{\lambda}\left(\frac{1}{h_{E}}-\frac{1}{h_{M}}\right)}-\left(\frac{1}{h_{M}}+\frac{1}{h_{E}}\right)\right].italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG [ square-root start_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ] . (6)

If for some (hM,hE)subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏(h_{M},h_{E})( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the value of P‚Å¢(hM,hE)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) obtained from (6) is negative, then it follows from the concavity of the objective function w.r.t. P‚Å¢(hM,hE)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) that the optimal value of P‚Å¢(hM,hE)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is 0. Thus the optimal power allocation policy at the transmitter is given by

P‚Å¢(hM,hE)=12‚Å¢[(1hE‚àí1hM)2+4Œª‚Å¢(1hE‚àí1hM)‚àí(1hM+1hE)]+,ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏12superscriptdelimited-[]superscript1subscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ24ùúÜ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})=\frac{1}{2}\left[\sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{h_{E}}-\frac{1}{h_{M}}\right)^{2}+\frac{4}{\lambda}\left(\frac{1}{h_{E}}-\frac{1}{h_{M}}\right)}-\left(\frac{1}{h_{M}}+\frac{1}{h_{E}}\right)\right]^{+},italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG [ square-root start_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (7)

where [x]+=max‚Å°{0,x}superscriptdelimited-[]ùë•0ùë•[x]^{+}=\max\{0,x\}[ italic_x ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_max { 0 , italic_x }, and the parameter ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª is a constant that satisfies the power constraint in (5) with equality. The secrecy capacity is then determined by substituting this optimal power allocation policy for P‚Å¢(hM,hE)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏P(h_{M},h_{E})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (4).

4 Only Main Channel CSI at the Transmitter

In this section, we assume that at the beginning of each coherence interval, the transmitter only knows the CSI of the main channel (legitimate receiver).

4.1 Optimal Power Allocation

We first characterize the secrecy capacity under this scenario in the following theorem.

Theorem 2

When only the channel gain of the legitimate receiver is known at the transmitter, the secrecy capacity is given by

Cs(M)=maxP‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢‚à¨[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))]+‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE,superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë†ùëÄsubscriptùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdouble-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏C_{s}^{(M)}~{}=~{}\max\limits_{P(h_{M})}\iint\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M})\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{},italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à¨ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (8)
such that¬†ùîº‚Å¢{P‚Å¢(hM)}‚â§P¬Ø.such that¬†ùîºùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ¬ØùëÉ\mbox{such that }\qquad\qquad{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M})\}~{}\leq~{}\bar{P}.such that blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } ‚â§ over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG . (9)

Proof:¬†¬† A detailed proof of achievability and the converse part is provided in the Appendix. Here, we outline the scheme used to show achievability. We use the following variable rate transmission scheme. During a coherence interval with main channel fading state hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the transmitter transmits codewords at rate log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ\log(1+h_{M}P(h_{M}))roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) with power P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). This variable rate scheme relies on the assumption of large coherence intervals and ensures that when hE>hMsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{E}>h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the mutual information between the source and the eavesdropper is upper bounded by log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ\log(1+h_{M}P(h_{M}))roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). When hE‚â§hMsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{E}\leq h_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this mutual information will be log‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ\log(1+h_{E}P(h_{M}))roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). Averaging over all the fading states, the average rate of the main channel is given by

‚à¨log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE,double-integral1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\iint\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E},‚à¨ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

while the information accumulated at the eavesdropper is

‚à¨log‚Å°(1+min‚Å°{hM,hE}‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE.double-integral1subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\iint\log\left(1+\min\{h_{M},h_{E}\}P(h_{M})\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}.‚à¨ roman_log ( 1 + roman_min { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Hence for a given power control policy P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the achievable perfect secrecy rate is given by

Rs(M)=‚à¨[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))]+‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE.superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëÄdouble-integralsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏R_{s}^{(M)}~{}=~{}\iint\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M})\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ‚à¨ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (10)

One can then optimize over all feasible power control policies P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to maximize the perfect secrecy rate. Finally, we observe that our secure message is hidden across different fading states (please refer to our proof for more details). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

We now derive the optimal power allocation policy that achieves the secrecy capacity under the main channel CSI assumption. Similar to Theorem¬†1, the objective function under this case is also concave, and using the Lagrangian maximization approach for solving (8), we get the following optimality condition.

‚àÇRs(M)‚àÇP‚Å¢(hM)=hM‚Å¢Pr‚Å¢(hE‚â§hM)1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM)‚àí‚à´0hM(hE1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhE‚àíŒª=0,superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚ÑéùëÄPrsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsuperscriptsubscript0subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùúÜ0\frac{\partial R_{s}^{(M)}}{\partial P(h_{M})}~{}=~{}\frac{h_{M}\textrm{Pr}\left(h_{E}\leq h_{M}\right)}{1+h_{M}P(h_{M})}-\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\left(\frac{h_{E}}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}-\lambda~{}=~{}0,divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG - ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œª = 0 ,

where ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª is a constant that satisfies the power constraint in (9) with equality. For any main channel fading state hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the optimal transmit power level P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is determined from the above equation. If the obtained power level turns out to be negative, then the optimal value of P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is equal to 0. This follows from the concavity of the objective function in (8) w.r.t. P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The solution to this optimization problem depends on the distributions f‚Å¢(hM)ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄf(h_{M})italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and f‚Å¢(hE)ùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏f(h_{E})italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In the following, we focus on the Rayleigh fading scenario with ùîº‚Å¢{hM}=Œ≥¬ØMùîºsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript¬ØùõæùëÄ{\mathbb{E}}\{h_{M}\}=\overline{\gamma}_{M}blackboard_E { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùîº‚Å¢{hE}=Œ≥¬ØEùîºsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript¬Øùõæùê∏{\mathbb{E}}\{h_{E}\}=\overline{\gamma}_{E}blackboard_E { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in detail. Specializing the optimality conditions to the Rayleigh fading scenario, it can be shown that the power level of the transmitter at any fading state hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained by solving the equation

(1‚àíe‚àí(hM/Œ≥¬ØE))‚Å¢(hM1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚àíŒª‚àí(1‚àíe‚àí(hM/Œ≥¬ØE))P‚Å¢(hM)+1superscriptùëísubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript¬Øùõæùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùúÜlimit-from1superscriptùëísubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript¬Øùõæùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ\displaystyle\left(1-e^{-(h_{M}/\overline{\gamma}_{E})}\right)\left(\frac{h_{M}}{1+h_{M}P(h_{M})}\right)-\lambda-\frac{\left(1-e^{-(h_{M}/\overline{\gamma}_{E})}\right)}{P(h_{M})}+\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) - italic_Œª - divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG +
exp‚Å°(1Œ≥¬ØE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))Œ≥¬ØE‚Å¢(P‚Å¢(hM))2‚Å¢[Ei‚Å¢(1Œ≥¬ØE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚àíEi‚Å¢(hMŒ≥¬ØE+1Œ≥¬ØE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))]=0.1subscript¬Øùõæùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript¬Øùõæùê∏superscriptùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ2delimited-[]Ei1subscript¬Øùõæùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄEisubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript¬Øùõæùê∏1subscript¬Øùõæùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ0\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\frac{\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}(P(h_{M}))^{2}}\left[\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)-\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{h_{M}}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}}+\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)\right]~{}=~{}0.divide start_ARG roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG [ Ei ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) - Ei ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ] = 0 .

If there is no positive solution to this equation for a particular hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then we set P‚Å¢(hM)=0ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ0P(h_{M})=0italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0. The secrecy capacity is then determined by substituting this optimal power allocation policy for P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (11).

We observe that, unlike the traditional ergodic fading scenario, achieving the optimal performance under a security constraint relies heavily on using a variable rate transmission strategy. This can be seen by evaluating the performance of a constant rate strategy where a single codeword is interleaved across infinitely many fading realizations. This interleaving will result in the eavesdropper gaining more information, than the destination, when its channel is better than the main channel, thereby yielding a perfect secrecy rate that is strictly smaller than that in (10). It is easy to see that the achievable perfect secrecy rate of the constant rate scheme, assuming a Gaussian codebook, is given by

maxP‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢‚à¨[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))]‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE,subscriptùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdouble-integraldelimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\max\limits_{P(h_{M})}\iint\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P(h_{M})\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P(h_{M})\right)\right]f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{},roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à¨ [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
such that¬†ùîº‚Å¢{P‚Å¢(hM)}‚â§P¬Ø.such that¬†ùîºùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ¬ØùëÉ\mbox{such that }\qquad\qquad{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M})\}\leq\bar{P}.such that blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } ‚â§ over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG .

Unlike the two previous optimization problems, the objective function in this optimization problem is not a concave function of P‚Å¢(hM)ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄP(h_{M})italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Using the Lagrangian formulation, we only get the following necessary KKT conditions for the optimal point.

P‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢[Œª‚àíhM1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM)+‚à´(hE1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhE]=0,ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdelimited-[]ùúÜsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏0P(h_{M})\left[\lambda-\frac{h_{M}}{1+h_{M}P(h_{M})}+\int\left(\frac{h_{E}}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}\right]~{}=~{}0,italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) [ italic_Œª - divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + ‚à´ ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = 0 ,
Œª‚â•hM1+hM‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM)‚àí‚à´(hE1+hE‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM))‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhE,ùúÜsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\lambda~{}\geq~{}\frac{h_{M}}{1+h_{M}P(h_{M})}-\int\left(\frac{h_{E}}{1+h_{E}P(h_{M})}\right)f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E},italic_Œª ‚â• divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG - ‚à´ ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
ùîº‚Å¢{P‚Å¢(hM)}=P¬Ø.ùîºùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ¬ØùëÉ{\mathbb{E}}\{P(h_{M})\}~{}=~{}\bar{P}.blackboard_E { italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } = over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG . (12)

4.2 On/Off Power Control

We now propose a transmission policy wherein the transmitter sends information only when the channel gain of the legitimate receiver hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exceeds a pre-determined constant threshold œÑ>0ùúè0\tau>0italic_œÑ > 0. Moreover, when hM>œÑsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùúèh_{M}>\tauitalic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_œÑ, the transmitter always uses the same power level PùëÉPitalic_P. However, it is crucial to adapt the rate of transmission instantaneously as log‚Å°(1+P‚Å¢hM)1ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ\log(1+Ph_{M})roman_log ( 1 + italic_P italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with hMsubscript‚ÑéùëÄh_{M}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is clear that for an average power constraint P¬Ø¬ØùëÉ\bar{P}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG, the constant power level used for transmission will be

P=P¬ØPr‚Å¢(hM>œÑ).ùëÉ¬ØùëÉPrsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùúèP~{}=~{}\frac{\bar{P}}{\textrm{Pr}(h_{M}>\tau)}~{}.italic_P = divide start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_œÑ ) end_ARG .

Using a similar argument as in the achievable part of Theorem¬†2, we get the perfect secrecy rate achieved by the proposed scheme, using Gaussian inputs, as

Rs(C‚Å¢P)=‚à´0‚àû‚à´œÑ‚àû[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P)‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P)]+‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE.superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùê∂ùëÉsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscriptùúèsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏R_{s}^{(CP)}~{}=~{}\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{\tau}^{\infty}\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}P\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}P\right)\right]^{+}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Specializing to the Rayleigh fading scenario, we get

P=P¬ØPr‚Å¢(hM>œÑ)=P¬Ø‚Å¢e(œÑ/Œ≥¬ØM),ùëÉ¬ØùëÉPrsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùúè¬ØùëÉsuperscriptùëíùúèsubscript¬ØùõæùëÄP~{}=~{}\frac{\bar{P}}{\textrm{Pr}(h_{M}>\tau)}~{}=~{}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}~{},italic_P = divide start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_œÑ ) end_ARG = over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œÑ / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and the secrecy capacity simplifies to

Rs(C‚Å¢P)=‚à´œÑ‚àû‚à´0hM[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P¬Ø‚Å¢e(œÑ/Œ≥¬ØM))‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P¬Ø‚Å¢e(œÑ/Œ≥¬ØM))]‚Å¢1Œ≥¬ØM‚Å¢e‚àí(hM/Œ≥¬ØM)‚Å¢1Œ≥¬ØE‚Å¢e‚àí(hE/Œ≥¬ØE)‚Å¢dhE‚Å¢dhM,superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùê∂ùëÉsuperscriptsubscriptùúèsuperscriptsubscript0subscript‚ÑéùëÄdelimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ¬ØùëÉsuperscriptùëíùúèsubscript¬ØùõæùëÄ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏¬ØùëÉsuperscriptùëíùúèsubscript¬ØùõæùëÄ1subscript¬ØùõæùëÄsuperscriptùëísubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript¬ØùõæùëÄ1subscript¬Øùõæùê∏superscriptùëísubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript¬Øùõæùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄR_{s}^{(CP)}=\int_{\tau}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}\bar{P}e^{(\tau/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\right)\right]\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}}e^{-(h_{M}/\overline{\gamma}_{M})}\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}}e^{-(h_{E}/\overline{\gamma}_{E})}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}~{},italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œÑ / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - which then simplifies to

One can then optimize over the threshold œÑùúè\tauitalic_œÑ to get the maximum achievable perfect secrecy rate.

Finally, we establish the asymptotic optimality of this on/off scheme as the available average transmission power P¬Ø‚Üí‚àû‚Üí¬ØùëÉ\bar{P}\to\inftyover¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ‚Üí ‚àû. For the on/off power allocation policy, we have

Rs(C‚Å¢P)=limP¬Ø‚Üí‚àû‚à´œÑ*‚àû‚à´0hMlog‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P1+hE‚Å¢P)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhE‚Å¢dhM.superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùê∂ùëÉsubscript‚Üí¬ØùëÉsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùúèsuperscriptsubscript0subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëÉ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëÉùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄR_{s}^{(CP)}=\lim_{\bar{P}\to\infty}~{}\int_{\tau^{*}}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\log\left(\frac{1+h_{M}P}{1+h_{E}P}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Taking œÑ*=0superscriptùúè0\tau^{*}=0italic_œÑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0, we get P=P¬ØùëÉ¬ØùëÉP=\bar{P}italic_P = over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG and

Rs(C‚Å¢P)superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùê∂ùëÉ\displaystyle R_{s}^{(CP)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_P ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â•\displaystyle\geq‚â• limP¬Ø‚Üí‚àû‚à´0‚àû‚à´0hMlog‚Å°((1/P¬Ø)+hM(1/P¬Ø)+hE)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhE‚Å¢dhMsubscript‚Üí¬ØùëÉsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1¬ØùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1¬ØùëÉsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ\displaystyle\lim_{\bar{P}\to\infty}~{}\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\log\left(\frac{(1/\bar{P})+h_{M}}{(1/\bar{P})+h_{E}}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG ( 1 / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (13)
=(a)ùëé\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{=}start_OVERACCENT ( italic_a ) end_OVERACCENT start_ARG = end_ARG ‚à´0‚àû‚à´0hMlimP¬Ø‚Üí‚àûlog‚Å°((1/P¬Ø)+hM(1/P¬Ø)+hE)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢d‚Å¢hE‚Å¢d‚Å¢hMsuperscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Üí¬ØùëÉ1¬ØùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1¬ØùëÉsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\lim_{\bar{P}\to\infty}~{}\log\left(\frac{(1/\bar{P})+h_{M}}{(1/\bar{P})+h_{E}}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG ( 1 / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=\displaystyle== ‚à´0‚àû‚à´0hMlog‚Å°(hMhE)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhE‚Å¢dhM=ùîº{hM>hE}‚Å¢{log‚Å°(hMhE)},superscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscriptùîºsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{h_{M}}\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}{\mathrm{d}}h_{M}~{}=~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\{h_{M}>h_{E}\}}\left\{\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)\right\},‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) } ,

where (a) follows from the Dominated Convergence Theorem, since

|log‚Å°((1/P¬Ø)+hM(1/P¬Ø)+hE)|‚â§|log‚Å°(hMhE)|,‚àÄP¬Øwhen¬†hM>hE,1¬ØùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ1¬ØùëÉsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏for-all¬ØùëÉwhen¬†hM>hE,\left|\log\left(\frac{(1/\bar{P})+h_{M}}{(1/\bar{P})+h_{E}}\right)\right|~{}\leq~{}\left|\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)\right|,\qquad\forall\bar{P}\quad\mbox{when $h_{M}>h_{E}$,}| roman_log ( divide start_ARG ( 1 / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 / over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | ‚â§ | roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) | , ‚àÄ over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG when italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

since ùîº‚Å¢{hM}<‚àûùîºsubscript‚ÑéùëÄ{\mathbb{E}}\{h_{M}\}<\inftyblackboard_E { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } < ‚àû, |‚à´01log‚Å°x‚Å¢d‚Å¢x|=1<‚àûsuperscriptsubscript01ùë•dùë•1\Big{|}\int_{0}^{1}\log x~{}{\mathrm{d}}x\Big{|}=1<\infty| ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_x roman_d italic_x | = 1 < ‚àû and f‚Å¢(hM),f‚Å¢(hE)ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏f(h_{M}),f(h_{E})italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are continuous and bounded.

Now under the full CSI assumption, we have

Cs(F)=ùîº{hM>hE}‚Å¢{log‚Å°(1P‚Å¢(hM,hE)+hM1P‚Å¢(hM,hE)+hE)}‚â§ùîº{hM>hE}‚Å¢{log‚Å°(hMhE)}.superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë†ùêπsubscriptùîºsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏1ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄ1ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚Ñéùê∏subscriptùîºsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏C_{s}^{(F)}~{}=~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\{h_{M}>h_{E}\}}\left\{\log\left(\frac{\frac{1}{P(h_{M},h_{E})}+h_{M}}{\frac{1}{P(h_{M},h_{E})}+h_{E}}\right)\right\}~{}\leq~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\{h_{M}>h_{E}\}}\left\{\log\left(\frac{h_{M}}{h_{E}}\right)\right\}.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_log ( divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) } ‚â§ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) } . (14)

From (13) and (14), it is clear that the proposed on/off power allocation policy that uses only the main channel CSI achieves the secrecy capacity under the full CSI assumption as P¬Ø‚Üí‚àû‚Üí¬ØùëÉ\bar{P}\to\inftyover¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ‚Üí ‚àû. Thus the absence of eavesdropper CSI at the transmitter does not reduce the secrecy capacity at high SNR values.

5 Numerical Results

As an additional benchmark, we first obtain the performance when the transmitter does not have any knowledge of both the main and eavesdropper channels (only receiver CSI). In this scenario, the transmitter is unable to exploit rate/power adaptation and always transmits with power P¬Ø¬ØùëÉ\bar{P}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG. It is straightforward to see that the achievable perfect secrecy rate in this scenario (using Gaussian inputs) is given by

Rs(R)superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëÖ\displaystyle R_{s}^{(R)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =\displaystyle== [‚à´0‚àû‚à´0‚àû[log‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P¬Ø)‚àílog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P¬Ø)]‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE]+superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0delimited-[]1subscript‚ÑéùëÄ¬ØùëÉ1subscript‚Ñéùê∏¬ØùëÉùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\displaystyle\left[\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\log\left(1+h_{M}\bar{P}\right)-\log\left(1+h_{E}\bar{P}\right)\right]f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}\right]^{+}[ ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) - roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) ] italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=\displaystyle== [‚à´0‚àûlog‚Å°(1+hM‚Å¢P¬Ø)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢dhM‚àí‚à´0‚àûlog‚Å°(1+hE‚Å¢P¬Ø)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhE]+,superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript01subscript‚ÑéùëÄ¬ØùëÉùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsuperscriptsubscript01subscript‚Ñéùê∏¬ØùëÉùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\displaystyle\left[\int_{0}^{\infty}\log\left(1+h_{M}\bar{P}\right)f(h_{M}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}-\int_{0}^{\infty}\log\left(1+h_{E}\bar{P}\right)f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{E}\right]^{+}~{},[ ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

which reduces to the following for the Rayleigh fading scenario

Rs(R)=[exp‚Å°(1Œ≥¬ØM‚Å¢P¬Ø)‚Å¢Ei‚Å¢(1Œ≥¬ØM‚Å¢P¬Ø)‚àíexp‚Å°(1Œ≥¬ØE‚Å¢P¬Ø)‚Å¢Ei‚Å¢(1Œ≥¬ØE‚Å¢P¬Ø)]+.superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëÖsuperscriptdelimited-[]1subscript¬ØùõæùëÄ¬ØùëÉEi1subscript¬ØùõæùëÄ¬ØùëÉ1subscript¬Øùõæùê∏¬ØùëÉEi1subscript¬Øùõæùê∏¬ØùëÉR_{s}^{(R)}~{}=~{}\left[\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}\bar{P}}\right)\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{M}\bar{P}}\right)-\exp\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}\bar{P}}\right)\textrm{Ei}\left(\frac{1}{\overline{\gamma}_{E}\bar{P}}\right)\right]^{+}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) Ei ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) - roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) Ei ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Thus when Œ≥¬ØE‚â•Œ≥¬ØMsubscript¬Øùõæùê∏subscript¬ØùõæùëÄ\overline{\gamma}_{E}\geq\overline{\gamma}_{M}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Rs(R)=0superscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëÖ0R_{s}^{(R)}=0italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. The results for the Rayleigh normalized-symmetric case (Œ≥¬ØM=Œ≥¬ØE=1subscript¬ØùõæùëÄsubscript¬Øùõæùê∏1\overline{\gamma}_{M}=\overline{\gamma}_{E}=1over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1) are presented in Fig.¬†2. It is clear that the performance of the on/off power control scheme is very close to the secrecy capacity (with only main channel CSI) for a wide range of SNRs and, as expected, approaches the secrecy capacities, under both the full CSI and main channel CSI assumptions, at high values of SNR. The performance of the constant rate scheme is much worse than the other schemes that employ rate adaptation. Here we note that the performance curve for the constant rate scheme might be a lower bound to the secrecy capacity (since the KKT conditions are necessary but not sufficient for non-convex optimization). We then consider an asymmetric scenario, wherein the eavesdropper channel is more capable than the main channel, with Œ≥¬ØM=1subscript¬ØùõæùëÄ1\overline{\gamma}_{M}=1over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and Œ≥¬ØE=2subscript¬Øùõæùê∏2\overline{\gamma}_{E}=2over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2. The performance results for this scenario are plotted in Fig.¬†3. Again it is clear from the plot that the performance of the on/off power control scheme is optimal at high values of SNR, and that rate adaptation schemes yield higher perfect secrecy rates than constant rate transmission schemes.

6 Conclusions

We have characterized the secrecy capacity of the slow fading channel with an eavesdropper under different assumptions on the available transmitter CSI. Our work establishes the interesting result that a non-zero perfectly secure rate is achievable in the fading channel even when the eavesdropper is more capable than the legitimate receiver (on the average). By contrasting this conclusion with the traditional AWGN scenario, one can see the positive impact of fading on enhancing the secrecy capacity. Furthermore, we proposed a low-complexity on/off power transmission scheme and established its asymptotic optimality. This optimality shows that the presence of eavesdropper CSI at the transmitter does not offer additional gains in the secrecy capacity for slow fading channels, at high enough SNR levels. The knowledge of the main channel CSI, however, is crucial since it is easy to see that the absence of this information leads to a zero secrecy capacity when the eavesdropper is more capable than the legitimate receiver on the average. Finally, our theoretical and numerical results established the critical role of appropriate rate adaptation in facilitating secure communications over slow fading channels.

Appendix A Proof of Theorem¬†1

We first prove the achievability of (4) by showing that for any perfect secrecy rate Rs<Cs(F)subscriptùëÖùë†superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë†ùêπR_{s}<C_{s}^{(F)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there exists a sequence of (2n‚Å¢Rs,n)superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëõ(2^{nR_{s}},n)( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_n ) block codes with average power P¬Ø¬ØùëÉ\bar{P}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG, equivocation rate Re>Rs‚àíœµsubscriptùëÖùëísubscriptùëÖùë†italic-œµR_{e}>R_{s}-\epsilonitalic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œµ, and probability of error Pen‚Üí0‚ÜísuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëíùëõ0P_{e}^{n}\to 0italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí 0 as n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\to\inftyitalic_n ‚Üí ‚àû. Let Rs=Cs(F)‚àí3‚Å¢Œ¥subscriptùëÖùë†superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë†ùêπ3ùõøR_{s}=C_{s}^{(F)}-3\deltaitalic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_F ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 italic_Œ¥ for some Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0italic_Œ¥ > 0. Consider a time-invariant AWGN channel with channel gains hM‚àà[hM,i,hM,(i+1))subscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñ1h_{M}\in[h_{M,i},h_{M,(i+1)})italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà [ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , ( italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and hE‚àà[hE,j,hE,(j+1))subscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëósubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëó1h_{E}\in[h_{E,j},h_{E,(j+1)})italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà [ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , ( italic_j + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). for sufficiently large nùëõnitalic_n. Note that the expression in (17) is obtained by considering the worst case scenario hM=hM,i,hE=hE,(j+1)formulae-sequencesubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñsubscript‚Ñéùê∏subscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëó1h_{M}=h_{M,i},h_{E}=h_{E,(j+1)}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , ( italic_j + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that yields the smallest perfect secrecy rate.

For transmitting the message index w‚àà{1,‚ãØ,2n‚Å¢Rs}ùë§1‚ãØsuperscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖùë†w\in\{1,\cdots,2^{nR_{s}}\}italic_w ‚àà { 1 , ‚ãØ , 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, we first map wùë§witalic_w to the indices {wi‚Å¢j}subscriptùë§ùëñùëó\{w_{ij}\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } by dividing the n‚Å¢RsùëõsubscriptùëÖùë†nR_{s}italic_n italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bits which determine the message index into sets of ni‚Å¢j‚Å¢(Rs)i‚Å¢jsubscriptùëõùëñùëósubscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëñùëón_{ij}(R_{s})_{ij}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bits. The transmitter uses a multiplexing strategy and transmits codewords {xwi‚Å¢j}subscriptùë•subscriptùë§ùëñùëó\{x_{w_{ij}}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } at codeword rate log‚Å°(1+hM,i‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,i,hE,j))1subscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëó\log\left(1+h_{M,i}P(h_{M,i},h_{E,j})\right)roman_log ( 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) and perfect secrecy rate (Rs)i‚Å¢jsubscriptsubscriptùëÖùë†ùëñùëó(R_{s})_{ij}( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, when the channel is in state si‚Å¢jsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós_{ij}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\to\inftyitalic_n ‚Üí ‚àû, this scheme achieves the perfect secrecy rate (using the ergodicity of the channel),

Rs=‚àëi=1q1‚àëj=1q2[log(1+hM,i‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,i,hE,j)1+hE,(j+1)‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,i,hE,j))]+Pr(hM,i‚â§hM<hM,(i+1),hE,j‚â§hE<hE,(j+1)).R_{s}~{}=~{}\sum_{i=1}^{q_{1}}\sum_{j=1}^{q_{2}}\left[\log\left(\frac{1+h_{M,i}P(h_{M,i},h_{E,j})}{1+h_{E,(j+1)}P(h_{M,i},h_{E,j})}\right)\right]^{+}\textrm{Pr}\left(h_{M,i}\leq h_{M}<h_{M,(i+1)},h_{E,j}\leq h_{E}<h_{E,(j+1)}\right).italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , ( italic_j + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , ( italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , ( italic_j + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Thus for a fixed Œ¥ùõø\deltaitalic_Œ¥, we can find a sufficiently large nùëõnitalic_n such that

Rs‚â•‚àëi=1q1‚àëj=1q2[log(1+hM,i‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,i,hE,j)1+hE,(j+1)‚Å¢P‚Å¢(hM,i,hE,j))]+Pr(hM,i‚â§hM<hM,(i+1),hE,j‚â§hE<hE,(j+1))‚àíŒ¥.R_{s}~{}\geq~{}\sum_{i=1}^{q_{1}}\sum_{j=1}^{q_{2}}\left[\log\left(\frac{1+h_{M,i}P(h_{M,i},h_{E,j})}{1+h_{E,(j+1)}P(h_{M,i},h_{E,j})}\right)\right]^{+}\textrm{Pr}\left(h_{M,i}\leq h_{M}<h_{M,(i+1)},h_{E,j}\leq h_{E}<h_{E,(j+1)}\right)-\delta.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , ( italic_j + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Pr ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , ( italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , ( italic_j + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Œ¥ . (18)

For asymptotically large nùëõnitalic_n, using the ergodicity of the channel, the average power of the multiplexing scheme satisfies

‚àëi=1q1‚àëj=1q2P‚Å¢(hM,i,hE,j)‚Å¢‚à´hM,ihM,(i+1)‚à´hE,jhE,(j+1)f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhEsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëû1superscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùëû2ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëósuperscriptsubscriptsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëñ1superscriptsubscriptsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëósubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëó1ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{q_{1}}\sum_{j=1}^{q_{2}}P(h_{M,i},h_{E,j})\int_{h_{M,i}}^{h_{M,(i+1)}}\int_{h_{E,j}}^{h_{E,(j+1)}}f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M , ( italic_i + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , ( italic_j + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
‚â§(a)ùëé\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{\leq}start_OVERACCENT ( italic_a ) end_OVERACCENT start_ARG ‚â§ end_ARG ‚à´0‚àû‚à´0‚àûP‚Å¢(hM,hE)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hM)‚Å¢f‚Å¢(hE)‚Å¢dhM‚Å¢dhE‚Å¢‚â§(b)‚Å¢P¬Ø,superscriptsubscript0superscriptsubscript0ùëÉsubscript‚ÑéùëÄsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëìsubscript‚ÑéùëÄùëìsubscript‚Ñéùê∏differential-dsubscript‚ÑéùëÄdifferential-dsubscript‚Ñéùê∏ùëè¬ØùëÉ\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{\infty}P(h_{M},h_{E})f(h_{M})f(h_{E}){\mathrm{d}}h_{M}{\mathrm{d}}h_{E}~{}~{}\overset{(b)}{\leq}~{}~{}\bar{P},‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_OVERACCENT ( italic_b ) end_OVERACCENT start_ARG ‚â§ end_ARG over¬Ø start_ARG italic_P end_ARG ,

Now since
